nodes.text: His suggestion is disturbing unworkable and potentially dangerous.
Addiction cannot be cured by implementing his suggestions
Locking up addicts against their will would not only violate their rights; it would be likely to prove counter-productive.
If implementing Walter's suggestions cannot cure addicts and will be counterproductive the suggestions are disturbing unworkable and potentially dangerous

Drug workers talk about a  circuit-breaker  the event that triggers a person's decision to quit - a long-suffering partner walking out a valued job being lost. The addict realises what they stand to lose if they don't stop using.  This realisation is an internal one: the decision to quit drugs cannot be enforced from the outside. Addiction means the person has lost control over their drug use. The addiction cannot be  cured  by reducing still further that person's control over their own lives and circumstances as Watters is suggesting.
Locking up drug addicts against their will will decrease their control over their lives and circumstances
This may be a recipe for getting the addict straight back on the gear again
If something may be a recipe for getting the addict on the gear again it is likely that some addicts will get on the gear again
an excellent emotional recipe for getting straight back on the gear again
The newly  clean  addict may also feel violated traumatised and betrayed by their detention
If the addict may feel betrayed by his family and if feeling betrayed may cause one to get back on the gear again it may be a recipe for the addict's getting straight back on the gear again.

However much they want to help if your loved ones have conspired to have you thrown in the slammer against your will - and many addicts will see it that way - you're hardly going to pop round to their place for a cuppa and a chat when you get out. Broken trust is not an easy thing to mend.
A newly clean addict will sometimes have been put in jail by his loved ones

you might be able to physically clear drugs from a person's system with the aid of a solid door and a deadlock but what are the emotional consequences of forcing them to endure an involuntary and painful drug withdrawal without being psychologically prepared or even willing to do so?    Has Watters considered what would happen once they were released? People use drugs to block out painful underlying problems and those problems won't dissolve after a mandatory drying-out period.
If drugs are used to block out problems and these problems remain after the drying out period the addict is likely to use drugs again
